user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_CloseAllFiles:
```c
int32 OS_CloseAllFiles(void)
{
    int32            return_code;
    int32            close_code;
    OS_object_iter_t iter;

    return_code = OS_SUCCESS;

    OS_ObjectIdIterateActive(LOCAL_OBJID_TYPE, &iter);

    while (OS_ObjectIdIteratorGetNext(&iter))
    {
        /* call OS_close() on the entry referred to by the iterator */
        close_code = OS_ObjectIdIteratorProcessEntry(&iter, OS_FileIteratorClose);
        if (close_code != OS_SUCCESS)
        {
            return_code = close_code;
        }
    }

    OS_ObjectIdIteratorDestroy(&iter);

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: OS_CloseAllFiles itself has no function parameters, so there is no risk of this function violating Rule 17.8 by modifying its own parameters. The only places that could involve modification of function parameters are the calls that pass the address of the local iterator ("&iter") to other functions: these callees receive a pointer parameter and must not modify the pointer parameter itself (they may modify the pointed-to object). All other lines (local variable declarations and assignments, the loop control, the return statement, and the use of value arguments such as LOCAL_OBJID_TYPE or the function pointer OS_FileIteratorClose) do not involve passing or modifying a function parameter and therefore do not need investigation for Rule 17.8 compliance.
